bibl.title: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Florence M. Read, October 31, 1924

div1.p: Laura Carter sends Read a financial statement concerning Henry Carter's work on his history of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Florence M. Read, October 31, 1924

opener.dateline:
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
October 31, 1924.

div1.p:
How kind and how thoughtful you are! Yes, it is “about time
for another statement” about Father's work on the "History of Yellow
Fever, which I had been postponing because I have generally waited
three months before sending one in. With your letter at hand, how-
ever, I shall not wait any longer, the more so as it probably will
be better (if equally convenient to yourselves) to send in state-
ments by the month rather than quarterly.

list.item:
1: Father then has worked on the "History of Yellow Fever:
May 17, 1924 to June 17, 1924---------- 1 month
June 17, " to June 30, " --------- 12 days
Sept 20, " to Sept 30, " ---------- 10 "
Oct. 1, " to Oct. 31, " ---------- 1 month.
---------------------
Total---2 months & 22 days.

2: The expenses incurred in writing the History of Yellow
Fever during this time amount to $95.43, which is covered
by the $100.00 received in advance, which was included in
the check sent for the work ending on May 16, 1924.

div1.p:
With very best wishes, in which I know Father would join did he
know I was writing,

Miss Florence M. Read,
Assistant Secretary,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.

Lee is coming Tuesday = tomorrow
to put up some new swings
in the back yard. And
Ruth Grover, one of my friends
is coming home from school
with me.

I am planning to
have a circus when
I get the new swings.

The men came to take
our radio and fix it.
I don know what was
the matter with.

I recon this is all I have
to say.
This is the way to skilpot
